snippet: Only about half of the 300 people sought to monitor the cease-fire have made commitments to do so, the top United Nations peacekeeping official said.
abstract: United Nations announces that it has recruited only about half of the 300-member contingent of monitors it had hoped to station in Syria, where violence continues despite a cease-fire agreement; also reports that Syrian authorities have not yet removed heavy weapons from population centers as required under the plan.

byline.original: By RICK GLADSTONE and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
byline.contributor: Rick Gladstone reported from New York, and Neil MacFarquhar from Beirut, Lebanon. Hwaida Saad contributed reporting from Beirut, and Alan Cowell from London.

lead_paragraph: Only about half of the 300 people sought to monitor the cease-fire have made commitments to do so, the top United Nations peacekeeping official said.

headline.seo: Recruitment for Syria Monitors is Slow, U.N. Says
headline.main: U.N. Seeks More Recruits to Monitor Truce in Syria
headline.print_headline: U.N. Seeks More Recruits To Monitor Truce in Syria
